title: At Louis Vuitton, Marketing Is a Four-Letter Word
text:
Louis Vuitton CEO Michael Burke presented his company’s latest sales pitch yesterday at the airport.

No, it wasn’t due to a dire TSA misunderstanding or catastrophic flight delays. It was by choice—a choice he made with Vuitton’s womenswear artistic director Nicolas Ghesquière to stage a fashion show at the TWA Flight Center, the refurbished Eero Saarinen–designed terminal at New York’s John F. Kennedy International Airport. The occasion was the unveiling of Vuitton’s sixth annual cruise collection, featuring designs intended to arrive in stores during next winter’s chilly doldrums. Last night, Ghesquière sent out ’80s-inspired haute rockabilly styles, including a dress sequined in homage to the Chrysler Building, for an audience packed with celebrities such as Cate Blanchett, Emma Stone, Michelle Williams, and Julianne Moore.

“It took a certain amount of audacity to pull it off, because it’s not easy to do a fashion show inside an airport,” says Burke, 62.

The landmark site is the latest in a list of ultra-luxe Vuitton roadshow locations that includes an Oscar Niemeyer–designed museum in Rio de Janeiro and a John Lautner house in Palm Springs. The historic ’60s-era terminal has been closed for 18 years, and last night’s event marked a glittering revival before it opens to the public next week as the site of a new retro-inspired hotel.

The high-profile event is also a key part of Burke’s strategy as he tries to best last year’s revenue total for Vuitton—reportedly close to $12 billion. The brand offers leather goods, accessories, men’s and women’s clothing, perfume, fine jewelry and home design in over 460 stores worldwide, all without any standard vendor tools like wholesaling, licensing, end-of-season sales—and certainly no duty-free shops. That figure is higher than those of rivals Hermès and Gucci. (Louis Vuitton does not comment on figures.)

“Well, we don’t very often disclose it, and as Bernard [Arnault] said, you’ll have to wait until we hit $20 billion for the next time [we do],” says Burke.

He describes himself as co-managing the brand with Arnault. Burke began working with Bernard’s father, Jean, as an intern, and after graduating from the elite French business school EDHEC in 1980, he joined LVMH in 1986. Last year, LVMH had a record $53.5 billion in revenue, driven in large part by the success of Louis Vuitton. He and Arnault have no intention of slowing down, especially in a world where luxury market share is determined by such disparate elements as ultra-high-net worth individuals, social media influencers, international currency fluctuations, digital saturation, celebrity endorsements and real estate footprints.

“The difficult part is playing between the timely part of the business versus the timeless part of the business,” Burke says. “[The] cruise [show] allows us to tell a consistent story. If you just go from fashion week to fashion week, there are a lot of people who burn out.”

Models walk the runway during the Louis Vuitton Cruise 2020 Fashion Show at TWA Flight Center at JFK Airport on May 8, 2019 in New York City. Photo: ANGELA WEISS/AFP/Getty Images

The appeal of staging a cruise collection, Burke says, is what it does for Vuitton’s messaging: though the audience is only 1,500 guests, he estimates the event can ultimately reach an audience of half a billion through various online avenues—and all in sync with the one-time luggage-maker’s legacy of upscale travel and design. “It’s about creating desire and being patient,” he says. “A great cruise show, five years later, people are still talking about it.”

Last night’s show came just a week after other extravagant cruise shows: LVMH sister brand Christian Dior in Marrakech and Italian rival Prada in New York. It was also just days after the Metropolitan Museum of Art’s brand-crammed Costume Institute Gala where Ghesquière appeared alongside so-called “Friends of the House,” celebrities decked out in Louis Vuitton.

“The Met is the pinnacle of our business…other companies have different goals, but we want to show we are relevant in extreme fashion,” says Burke. He points out that many of the red-carpet styles are reinterpretations of ready-to-wear looks, thereby benefiting sales, albeit in limited quantities. Conversely, if a celebrity “wore a [one-of-a-kind] high jewelry necklace on those steps...you will have a very hard time selling it. Because the client of that $1 million piece of jewelry wants to be the only person who has it.”

Call all this whatever you want, just don’t call it marketing.

“We don’t do marketing,” says Burke. “Show a product, pitch it heavily—that’s fast-moving consumer goods, that’s not our business.”

He adds, “In our parlance, we call that, ‘Don’t burn the goods.’”

He also refuses to take what he calls “a fashion approach.”

“We enter everything as a trade and want to be a relevant player in that trade,” says Burke, who oversees 20,000 employees worldwide. He points to the perfumes, launched in 2016. “The world does not need another perfume. If you are going to exist in that realm, you are going to do something different. We tried to come up with a unique model.” All of the scents, which start at $250 and are contained in matching bottles meant to convey a sense of timeless consistency, have been developed by legendary perfumer Jacques Cavallier Belletrud, and are sold in only 250 global Louis Vuitton stores.

“We don’t do focus groups, we don’t survey them, we don’t do blind-tests,” Burke says. “It’s not fashion-driven—that business model went out a long time ago.

In this spirit, he says that for the time-being, he will not be embarking on any new product categories and that Vuitton will be abstaining from brand collaborations following 2017’s much-hyped dalliance with cult streetwear brand Supreme. “We didn’t need Supreme,” he says. “If I had needed Supreme, I would have done $1 billion, I would have done it for a year. But we sold out after three weeks. Our entire model is sustainable growth.”

He has found that products by his recently appointed menswear artistic director, Virgil Abloh, can sell even faster than streetwear collaborations. Meanwhile, rumors of a rivalry between Abloh and Ghesquière have been swirling. “Louis Vuitton is too big for any singular individual, whether on the management side or the design side,” says Burke. “They are very respectful of each other and each one knows that the other one is different. They are engaging Vuitton from different vantage points: one is from a feminine, couture side, and the other one is from a masculine design side.”

He compares Abloh to the late Karl Lagerfeld (whom Burke worked with at Fendi), and sees Abloh and Ghesquière as synergistic personalities.

“They are not butterflies—they don’t go from one season to the next,” he says. “Both are extremely attuned to the design world, and they have a very long-term view of their aesthetic...When I worked with John Galliano, every season he would invent a new woman.” He keeps in close contact with both designers with regular lunch dates and phone calls. “We don’t go through briefs,” he says. “It’s a relationship of trust. Each side understands that they need the other one.”

They also both understand fashion’s new landscape, wherein social media has pried open its gilded gates. “Everyone wants to be behind-the-scenes,” Burke says. But “when I started in this business, photographers were not allowed in runway shows or showrooms, because everyone was paranoid that that was how you got knocked off.”

Though he welcomes the shift, he has had to cope with high-profile fakes, including logo’d tracksuits worn by music stars Bad Bunny and Billie Eilish during recent concert appearances at the Coachella music festival. Burke doesn’t rule out legal action against the bootlegs’ creator, Imran Moosvi, who works under the name Imran Potato, but he says that “Lawsuits are not a good solution—this is the ransom of success.” He points to the early ’90s unauthorized Vuitton renditions created by Harlem tailor Dapper Dan. “It’s hard to put the toothpaste back in the tube,” Burke says. “My typical attitude is to leave it up to Nicolas and Virgil.”

Moosvi commented via text message, “We should collab”—referring to the idea of jointly creating products with Vuitton.

Burke also has a counterintuitive attitude about the trending debate over online retail versus brick-and-mortar.

“It’s irrelevant for me,” he says. “It’s almost as if someone asked me what’s the percentage of sales using Visa versus MasterCard. I’m not in the business of being a payment provider. I’m in the business of selling experiences and objects.” He says that he views his clientele as “100% online and 100% brick and-mortar.”

Ask him about what moves should be made at Fendi following the death of Lagerfeld, the brand’s longtime women’s wear designer, and Burke parries, “Bernard is the only one I’ve told what I think.”

“My other day job was fixing companies—everytime Bernard bought something, I was sent in to fix it,” he says. “When we bought Dior, it had a broken business model based on licensing, so we had to fix that. Fendi was based on uncontrolled wholesale, so we had to fix that. When I went the first time around to Louis Vuitton back in the ’90s, we had not been able to position it as a European luxury brand, so we needed to fix that. That’s what I do.”

“After 35 years in the luxury business, I know how difficult it is to fix things. So everything I do now at Vuitton is making sure that after me, nobody has to fix anything.”
description: Ahead of Louis Vuitton’s cruise show, CEO Michael Burke talks about how to sustain global growth, how Nicolas Ghesquière and Virgil Abloh co-exist and why Vuitton doesn’t need another Supreme collaboration any time soon
